_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Detectors, Ammonia Alarms, Daily Rounds

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Roundys' Westville Division, 6500 South U. S. 421 Westville, In. 46391 is situated on 21.5 acres. The area around Roundys' property is mostly flat treeless farmland.
There are a few houses and some businesses within a half-mile of the property lines. There is a Correctional Facility about three quarters of a mile housing about 2500 inmates.
The town of Westville is north of this facility approximately 2.5 miles. There are about 800 residents in the town and about 600 rural residents. The town has a volunteer fire department and a Town Hall with three active Police Officers. There are three Restaurants in Westville. Two of which are Truck Stop fueling stations.
Roundys' warehouse employs approximately 400 associates. Their jobs would include Supervision and Management, Truck drivers and Truck / Trailer mechanics. Selectors for order picking, High Lift, Fork Truck Operators, Auditors and Vehicle and Building Maintenance, Sanitation.
This facility is a well-maintained and orderly operation. We have a low percent of accidents or injuries. The new hire training is top of the line with yearly training and documentation.
All new employees are given a tour of the facility. During the tour they are shown areas of high concentrations of ammonia, such as vessels, piping, and compressors. They are also told of the hazards of ammonia and shown the evacuation routes in the event of a release.
There are four meeting areas depending on wind direction. In each section of the Facility are directional maps in frames mounted to the walls. Each associate knows the meeting areas when the evacuation and wind direction are given over Public Address System. The Public Address System has a generator back up system in the event of a power outage from the Utility Company (NIPSCO). Twice yearly an emergency drill is conducted. All associates must exit the building for the drill and go to a pre-designated meeting area until the all clear is given by the supervisor of their area of work assignmen

t. They are instructed to use the buddy system. If someone is missing from an area and is not at the meeting area, the Hazmat commander will be notified the team can make a rescue.
The Hazmat Team Consists of a Commander, Captain, two Entry personal, two Decon personal, two Laision personal. Also a first aid and the Safety Director.
The Hazmat Cart has over $60,000 in tools and rescue equipment. The team also has the local volunteer fire department to assist in any release situation. Also to assist is
 
the LaPorte county Hazmat team should the need arise for more responders.
Roundys' has twelve cold storage rooms. The coldest room is the ice cream room, labeled Freezer #1 which is 4,620 square feet. The warmest room is 45¿. This is the produce dock. Additionally, there are dry storage areas which are not refrigerated. The entire Perishable area is monitored with ammonia sensors. They are set at 50 P. P. .M. and wired to the Maintenance Department and Security Control Center.
When an alarm registers at a location, it is investigated by a trained Maintenance Associate. All Maintenance Associates are trained to recognize and initiate an ammonia evacuation procedure should the need arise.
There has not been any major ammonia releases at this facility for over fifteen years.
There has been major modification to this facility (2000) with the addition of 126,000 square feet of new cold storage. There are three ammonia compressors, 38 evaporators and 3 condensers. There are over 1,000 valves associated with the ammonia system. All piping is of sound construction and 90% is under insulation. There is one Engine room. The engine room has three ammonia screw compressors.
The three condensers are IMECO, with 3500 tons of refrigeration. All components are inspected yearly in our Mechanical Integrity Audit. It is controlled by the staff and an independent company (Wagner-Meinert, Inc.). All discrepancies are dealt with swiftly by the Maintenance Department.
Daily logs are kept i

n the control room as to how many changes are made to the ammonia system. Forms are filled out for auto verses manual operation.
The P.S.M. manuals are kept up to date on a daily basis. Records, work schedules, and procedures on the ammonia system are recorded and filed daily. Also process teaching logs are used to inform each shift of any new changes.
This is a well maintained and highly respected facility. Many of our contractors have noted how well documented and clean areas of ammonia are kept.
